column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Mary Cockcroft :
#Text=SOS Children[ 's Villages ] is a " club " of member charities in 130 countries helping orphans and vulnerable children .
#Text=The club elects SOS-Kinderdorf International as secretary .
#Text=SOS is a large organisation whose members in aggregate turned over $1bn in 2007 , and whose projects include owning and running 192 schools and family-based care for 70,000 children .

#Text=However much of these funds are raised locally , with for example the member charities in each of India , Pakistan and South Africa raise considerably more funds in their own country than SOS UK does from the UK .

#Text=Nonetheless SOS Children UK principally raises funds to finance projects in the developing world , and has only financially small projects in the UK ( such as the Schools Wikipedia , which is very low cost because of extensive use of volunteers ) .
#Text=This year we expect about 80 % of our UK income will leave the UK for overseas SOS associations , and some of the remaining 20 % will pay for project oversight .
#Text=We do not spend money in the UK on Direct Mail or TV advertising .
#Text=Our UK office is involved in overseeing projects we finance and a small number of high-skilled volunteers from the UK help overseas .
#Text=However around 98 % of SOS staff worldwide are local nationals , as are most volunteers .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=How much work does the UK charity actually carry out within the home country ?
#Text=Are there failings within the government system for orphans and other needy children that you feel obliged to remedy ?
#Text=MC :
#Text=We are deeply unhappy about the situation of children in out-of-home care in the UK .
#Text=However our care model of 168 hour-a-week resident mothers does not fit with the UK philosophy for children without parental care .

#Text=Internationally SOS always has a policy of sharing best practice and we are working to improve understanding of our way of working , which appears to us to have far better outcomes than the existing one in the UK .
#Text=Ultimately though the legal responsibility for these children lies with government and we cannot remedy anything without their invitation .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=Who first came up with the idea of doing a vetted Wikipedia extract ?
#Text=What was the impetus ? Was it more for the developing world than first world ?
#Text=Andrew Cates :
#Text=I honestly cannot remember who first suggested it , but it came from somewhere in the Wikipedia community rather than from the charity .
#Text=The original product was very much pitched at the developing world where the Internet is only available if at all over an expensive phone line .

#Text=I worked in West Africa 1993-1996 and I know well at how thirsty for knowledge people are and how ingenious they will be in overcoming technical obstacles if the need for infrastructure is removed .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=In reading past year 's announcements there 's some pride in the project being picked up and used in the first world , was this expected or a pleasant surprise ?
